reviews.review_msg: no one teaches this class better than Dr Ro. she chose such an interesting topic for this class and the discussions and class activities were very engaging. overall such a fun class especially during the facilitated discussion weeks. doing this as an intersession was quite intense tho so prepare to read a lot and participate a lot in class.

This was one of my favourite, most engaging classes at SFU. Dr. Ro is an expert at facilitating discussion and encouraging participation from everyone in class. Since it was a small class (~25 students), it was easy to ask questions and get helped when needed. Dr. Ro is also very accommodating and understanding with students. Thank you Dr. Ro!
One of my favourite profs, shes super engaging and makes the content enjoyable to learn

Currently taking this class with Dr. T, who is good at her stuff, she brings bagel/donuts/grapes to class because its a morning class, lots of room for interaction between students. Says the final is an oral exam. Submitted one assignment since wk2, yet to get feedback (wk6). On average you read 4 articles before her lecture

Susan was the best prof I had at SFU. She appreciates effort in class and attentiveness. She also talks to you/treats you like adults. If you attend her classes, listen to her feedback on papers, and keep an open mind, you will breeze by in her classes. LOVED every minute of this course.

My favorite class ive taken, ever. You MUST know how to write to do well but everything else is just how well you are at critical thinking and out of the box methods. I was doubtful at first but Susan always was available and interested in helping out.
He's the friendliest prof I've ever seen. I feel very comfortable around him.

Milad was very engaging. The lectures passed by quickly. However, expectations for assignments were unclear, in contrast to the very specific criteria that he used for evaluation, which was mostly left until end of term. Before taking this class (HSCI 485), you should know that grading was unpredictable and harsher compared to other HSCI courses.

The class content itself was very interesting, however, the grading scheme for the assignments is very unclear and there is too much information packed into projects with strict time constraints. This made it challenging to dive deep into the material and deliver quality work without feeling rushed.

Dr. Parpouchi is my favourite professor I have had at SFU. Incredibly knowledgeable and motivated about his field of study, and conveys this passion during lectures. Looks for participation and a willingness to learn, he isn't always looking for you to have the right answer, but rather to try and participate. Super manageable if you're engaged!

Milad is my favourite. His lectures are interesting and hes funny and very knowledgeable and passionate. Hes so caring and open to discussion. 2 group projects and a presentation was rough but it is a seminar. Still super fun class and prof, take a class with Milad if you have the chance!

Milad is the best prof you will ever have in health sciences.The level of care and respect he has for his students is unmatched. Super funny with engaging lectures if you are interested in the subject. Multiple weekly readings and group presentations like most seminar classes but he makes you feel very comfortable to speak in class. 100% recommend!
The worst prof in HSCI faculty at SFU, if not the worst prof in the entire university
Interesting class if you liked content of HSCI 319. But be aware that it is not an easy class. A lot of readings and writing, and you need to be somewhat skilled in philosophy.
